Line 12: Line 12:  
Morality has two principal meanings:
 
Morality has two principal meanings:
 
* In its "descriptive" sense, ''morality'' refers to [[Value (personal and cultural)|personal or cultural values]], [[code of conduct|codes of conduct]] or social [[mores]] that distinguish between right and wrong in the [[human society]]. Describing morality in this way is not making a claim about what is objectively right or wrong, but only referring to what is considered right or wrong by an individual or some group of [[people]] (such as a religion). This sense of the term is addressed by [[descriptive ethics]].
 
* In its "descriptive" sense, ''morality'' refers to [[Value (personal and cultural)|personal or cultural values]], [[code of conduct|codes of conduct]] or social [[mores]] that distinguish between right and wrong in the [[human society]]. Describing morality in this way is not making a claim about what is objectively right or wrong, but only referring to what is considered right or wrong by an individual or some group of [[people]] (such as a religion). This sense of the term is addressed by [[descriptive ethics]].
−
* In its "[[normative]]" sense, ''morality'' refers directly to what is right and wrong, regardless of what specific individuals think. It could be defined as the conduct of the ideal "moral" person in a certain situation. This usage of the term is characterized by "definitive" statements such as "That person ''is'' [[Moral responsibility|morally responsible]]" rather than descriptive statements like "Many people believe that person is morally responsible." These ideas are explored in [[normative ethics]]. The normative sense of morality is often challenged by [[moral nihilism]] (which rejects the existence of any moral truths)<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gert|first=Bernard|title=The Definition of Morality|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Fall 2008 Edition) Edward N. Zalta (ed.)|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, CSLI, Stanford University|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2008/entries/morality-definition/|accessdate=January 28, 2011}}</ref> and supported by [[moral realism]] (which supports the existence of moral truths). ako'y nag dabog kaya lumindol xa bagiuo.uminit ulo q kaya pumutok ang pinatubo,..mga PI nyo!!!!!
+
* In its "[[normative]]" sense, ''morality'' refers directly to what is right and wrong, regardless of what specific individuals think. It could be defined as the conduct of the ideal "moral" person in a certain situation. This usage of the term is characterized by "definitive" statements such as "That person ''is'' [[Moral responsibility|morally responsible]]" rather than descriptive statements like "Many people believe that person is morally responsible." These ideas are explored in [[normative ethics]]. The normative sense of morality is often challenged by [[moral nihilism]] (which rejects the existence of any moral truths)<ref>{{Cite web|last=Gert|first=Bernard|title=The Definition of Morality|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Fall 2008 Edition) Edward N. Zalta (ed.)|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, CSLI, Stanford University|url=http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/fall2008/entries/morality-definition/|accessdate=January 28, 2011}}</ref> and supported by [[moral realism]] (which supports the existence of moral truths).
−
